Many thanks go to the Burke Museum for making these recordings available. I would also like to thank Laurel Sercombe of UW’s Ethnomusicology Archives, who gave me the privilege to access these recordings. Special thanks go to the late Leon Metcalf, who spent about five years tape-recording elder speakers of Lushootseed during the 1950’s. I would also like to acknowledge the family members of the speakers in this study: Denise Bill (great-granddaughter of Annie Jack), Willard Bill, Jr. (great-grandson of Annie Jack), Elise Bill-Gerrish (great-great-granddaughter of Annie Jack and daughter of Denise Bill), Justice Bill (great-great-grandson of Annie Jack and son of Willard Bill, Jr.); and Hank Williams (grandson of Martha Lamont), his daughter, and his (and Martha’s) descendants. Most of all, I am strongly in debt to the speakers themselves: Annie Jack and Martha Lamont, renowned storytellers whose legacies will never be forgotten and forever be preserved in these recordings. May the language and spirit of Annie Jack and Martha Lamont continue to live on within their descendants.

In this study, I conduct the first acoustic analysis of affricates in Lushootseed (Coast Salish branch). The findings reveal that several acoustic measurements, such as VOT, release frication duration, intensity, spectral moments (Center of Gravity), and voice onset quality, characterize affricate contrasts with respect to their place of articulation and laryngeal type (i.e., voiced, voiceless, ejective). This study raises questions concerning (a) the acoustic-articulatory correlates of affricates, (b) typological classification of ejective affricates, and (c) the diachronic status of voiced affricates in Coast Salish languages.

Index Terms: affricates, ejectives, typology, Coast Salish

1. Introduction
Like other Salish languages, Lushootseed (a Coast Salish language spoken in the Puget Sound region of the Pacific Northwest) is known for having many obstruents in its phonemic inventory. Of the 37 consonants in Lushootseed, 31 are obstruents (i.e., 84% of consonants). Seven of these obstruents are affricates: Namely, /dz ts ts' dʒ tʃ tʃ' tɬ/. An interesting feature of Lushootseed is that Lushootseed has a set of voiced affricates /dz dʒ/›, which is not found in many Coast Salish languages. Although some research has examined obstruents for other Salish languages [1], [2], [3], only a few conducted a rigorous acoustic analysis of obstruents in these languages [2], [3]. Affricates are of particular interest to document because, despite being a ubiquitous class of sound across Salish languages, very little is known about affricates phonetically in Coast Salish. In this paper, I provide the first acoustic phonetic analysis of affricates in Lushootseed.

Cross-linguistically, ejectives are known to differ in several acoustic dimensions [3], [4], [5], [6], [7], [8], [9], [10], [11]. According to Lindau [13] and Kingston [4], [5], there are typological differences in the realization of ejectives. Lindau [13] and Kingston [4], [5] proposed a model that classifies distinct types of ejectives, where ejectives can be classified as either stiff or slack. Stiff ejectives are characterized by a silent period between the consonant release and voice onset, which results in a long Voice Onset Time (VOT). Moreover, stiff ejectives are achieved with increased longitudinal tension and medial compression of the vocal folds, which results in a raised f0 at voice onset and a tense or modal voice onset quality. Other characteristics of stiff ejectives include a sharp rise in the amplitude of the following vowel and a relatively intense burst. Slack ejectives, on the other hand, are characterized by a short VOT and little longitudinal tension, resulting in a depressed f0 and creaky quality at voice onset. Other characteristics of slack ejectives include a steep rise in amplitude of the following vowel and a normal burst intensity.

Table 1 provides a summary of the Lindau-Kingston model of stiff and slack ejectives.

| Acoustic Dimensions       | Stiff ejective | Slack ejective |
|---------------------------|----------------|---------------|
| VOT                       | Long           | Short         |
| f0 perturbation           | Raised         | Depressed     |
| Voice quality             | Modal or tense | Creaky        |
| Rise time                 | Fast           | Slow          |
| Burst intensity           | Intense        | Normal        |

Although typological research focuses on ejective stops, few studies have focused on ejective affricates. Percival [11], [12] found that ejective affricates have acoustic correlates that differ from those of ejective stops. This leads to the question of how the acoustic dimensions used to characterize ejective types apply for affricates. Moreover, it is typologically rare to find languages with a three-way laryngeal contrast in affricates.

Another goal of this paper is to address these questions by conducting an acoustic analysis of the three-way laryngeal affricate contrast (voiced, voiceless, ejective) in Lushootseed. Addressing these questions in this study can contribute towards our understanding of the typology of ejectives (and affricates in general) across languages and how the acoustics of the three-way laryngeal contrast of affricates is realized.

2. Methods
2.1. Recordings
Because there are no first language speakers of Lushootseed remaining, recordings from the archives were examined. These recordings come from the Metcalf Collection (part of the Burke Museum’s Special Collections), which are recordings that date to the 1950’s and were produced by the musicologist Leon Metcalf. These recordings were digitized with a sampling rate of 44.1kHz with a 32-bit depth. 11 of these recordings were examined (total duration of approximately 2 hours and 3 minutes), which are recordings of traditional Salish myths and private correspondences (i.e., these are recordings of connected (spontaneous) speech).

2.2. Speakers
Two speakers were examined: Annie Jack (AJ) and Martha Lamont (ML). Annie Jack was an elder speaker of Southern Lushootseed. She was born around the 1870’s or 1880’s and lived in the Muckleshoot Tribal reservation. Her living descendants include Denise Bill (great-granddaughter), Willard Bill, Jr. (great-grandson), Elise Bill-Gerrish (great-great-granddaughter and daughter of Denise Bill), and Justice Bill (great-great-grandson and son of Willard Bill, Jr.). 2.3. Measurements and Sampling Procedure

Duration, intensity, spectral moments, and voice onset quality measurements were extracted using Praat [14]. For duration measurements, following [15], [16], Voice Onset Time (VOT) and the duration of the affricates' release frication were measured. Decibels of Sound Pressure Level (dB SPL) was measured along the affricates release frication at five time points (10%, 30%, 50%, 70%, 90%).

For spectral moments, Center of Gravity (CoG) was measured. The method used comes from Shadle [17] and Forrest et al. [18]. Following Shadle [17], time-averaging was used by extracting multiple Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) power specturms along the release frication duration, where each window was extracted with a length of 5 ms. Each of these windowed DFTs were then averaged through a matrix of intensity and sampling frequencies for each token. CoG was then calculated from the time-averaged spectrums.

To examine the voice onset quality of affricates, fundamental frequency (f0), jitter, and amplitude rise (i.e., intensity difference) were examined. Average f0 was obtained at the voice onset (10% point) and the vowel midpoint (50% point). f0 was measured by interpolating the pitch track and then extracting the f0 from the voicing component of the vowel. Jitter was obtained from 30 ms windows at voice onset and the vowels midpoint. Voiced period marks (pulses) were generated in Praat. These marks were inspected for errors and corrected by hand if necessary. Jitter is the variation in the duration of successive fundamental frequency cycles [19]. The mean percent jitter ratio was calculated by taking the average absolute difference between consecutive pulses divided by the average period and multiplied by 100 [20]. Intensity (in dB SPL) was obtained at the voice onset (10% point) and at the vowels' peak amplitude. Jitter, f0, and intensity were normalized, as shown in Table 2.

Table 2: Formulas for normalized measurements

| Measurement       | Formula |
|-------------------|---------|
| f0 perturbation   | (f0 at onset) – (f0 at midpoint) |
| jitter perturbation | (jitter at onset) – (jitter at midpoint) |
| RMS amplitude difference | (RMS energy at vowel peak) – (RMS energy at vowel onset) |

f0 perturbation was calculated by subtracting the mean f0 at vowel onset from the mean f0 at vowel midpoint. Similarly, jitter perturbation was calculated by subtracting the mean jitter at voice onset by the mean jitter at the vowel midpoint. RMS amplitude difference was calculated by subtracting the intensity (in dB SPL) at the vowel's peak amplitude from the intensity at the vowel onset.

All seven affricates /dz ts ts' dʒ tʃ tʃ' tɬ/ were examined word-initially and word-medially (intervocalically). Figure 1 illustrates the ejective alveolar affricate /ts'/ ‹c̓› in (a) word-initial position, and (b) word-medial position. At least 20 or more observations of each affricate (10 or more from each speaker) were used for the analysis (see Table 3). However, fewer than 20 tokens of /dʒ/ ‹ǰ› were obtained because /dʒ/ ‹ǰ› occurred rarely in the data.

Table 3: Number of tokens for each affricate.

| Speaker   | dz | ts | ts' | dʒ | tʃ | tʃ' | tɬ |
|-----------|----|----|----|----|----|----|----|
| Annie Jack | 13 | 76 | 16 | 6  | 65 | 31 | 36 |
| Martha Lamont | 10 | 30 | 11 | 5  | 59 | 2  | 3  |
| Total     | 23 | 106| 27 | 11 | 124| 54 | 90 |

Figure 1: Ejective alveolar affricate /ts'/ ‹c̓› in (a) word-initial position, and (b) word-medial position.

2.4. Analysis

The data was fit into a linear mixed effects model to analyze the contrast of each affricate with respect to its place of articulation and laryngeal type (i.e., voiced, voiceless, ejective). The package lme4 was used [21], where a t-value of 2 or greater was considered statistically significant. Each acoustic measure was used as dependent variables, while place of articulation (i.e., alveolar, post-alveolar, lateral) and laryngeal type (i.e., voiced, voiceless, ejective) were used as fixed effects. Speakers and words were treated as random effects, where place of articulation was used as a random slope for measures of duration, intensity, and spectral moment; while laryngeal type was used as a random slope for measures of duration and voice onset quality. The following equation was used to analyze the contrast across affricates with respect to iṭs' acoustic dimensions:

\[ \text{Measurements} \sim \text{Place} + \text{Laryngeal Type} + (\text{Place}, \text{Laryngeal Type} | \text{Speaker}) + (1 | \text{Word}) \]

3. Results

3.1. Duration measurements

The VOT and release frication duration for each affricate is illustrated in Figure 2. For VOT across each laryngeal type, ejective affricates are significantly longer than voiced (β = 124.753, SE = 7.219, t = 17.281) and voiceless (β = 26.118, SE = 4.939, t = 5.289) affricates. It should be noted that there were instances where /dz/ had a positive VOT, which can be observed in Figure 2a (where the VOT for /dz/ spans across both positive and negative values along the y-axis). The realization of /dz/ ‹dᶻ› as devoiced (i.e., positive VOT) usually occurred in word-initial position."}

### 3.2. Intensity characteristics

Figure 3 illustrates intensity at five time points for each affricate with respect to their laryngeal type and place of articulation. As Figure 3 illustrates, there is a rising intensity at the 90% time point for voiced affricates, a falling intensity at the 90% time point for ejectives, and in-between for voiceless affricates. Voiced affricates have a significantly greater intensity at 90% than voiceless affricates ($\beta = 3.867$, SE = 0.879, $t = 3.867$) and voiceless affricates significantly greater than ejectives ($\beta = 6.325$, SE = 1.366, $t = 4.632$). Interestingly, the lateral ejective affricate is characterized by a falling intensity throughout the entire frication period (from 10% to 90%). This contrasts from alveolar and post-alveolar affricates, where there is a rising intensity from 10% up to a bout 50% or 70%, and then a fall.

### 3.3. Spectral moment: Center of Gravity (CoG)

CoG for each affricate can be observed in Figure 4. The CoG for the alveolar place of articulation was significantly greater than post-alveolar ($\beta = 645.306$, SE = 99.337, $t = 6.496$), and post-alveolar greater than lateral ($\beta = 1061.082$, SE = 295.226, $t = 3.594$).

4. Discussion
The current findings reveal that there are several acoustic dimensions that characterize affricate contrasts in Lushootseed. Duration, Center of Gravity (CoG), intensity, and voice onset quality are good measures that characterize the affricate contrast with respect to their place of articulation and laryngeal type. The findings pose interesting problems towards (a) the acoustic-articulatory correlates of affricates, (b) typological classification of ejectives, and (c) diachronic status of voiced affricates in Coast Salish.

4.1. Acoustic-articulatory correlates of affricates
CoG was found to differentiate affricates in Lushootseed, suggesting differences in place of articulation as is typically found across languages [22], where alveolar > post-alveolar > lateral.

CoG for post-alveolars occurred in the low-mid frequency range. However, CoG for the alveolars is relatively lower than CoG of alveolars typically observed in other languages [18], [22], [23]. Alveolars tend to show peaks well above 7kHz [24], [25], [26]. Unfortunately, these peaks were not traceable in the speech signal from some of these recordings because of the upper frequency cutoff of the microphone signal, where the cutoff could be observed near 7kHz. This may have obscured measures of CoG for the voiceless alveolar affricate. However, relative differences in the affricates' place of articulation can be inferred.

The current findings reveal that the lateral place of articulation differs in CoG and intensity when compared with laterals in other languages [11], [12], [22], [23], [27]. However, the CoG for the lateral ejective affricate was significantly lower than post-alveolars in Lushootseed. It is possible that the oral release for the lateral ejective affricate was made posteriorly along the sides of the palate. The more posterior the constriction, the lower the frequency of the main peak [17], [22], [23], [27]. However, it is also possible that the low CoG was due to the length of the side channels during the release. If the constriction was made more posteriorly along the sides of the palate, this would create a longer channel along the buccal cavity for air to flow through following the release, which may correlate with the low CoG. This suggests that the lateral ejective affricate in Lushootseed may involve a different articulatory target when compared with other languages.

4.2. Typological classification of ejectives
The current findings support the view that there are more variable realizations of ejectives across languages and that ejectives cannot simply be divided into either stiff or slack, [3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]. There are several problems with classifying ejective affricates under the Lindau-Kingston model in Lushootseed. The Lindau-Kingston model assumes that VOT is longer for stiff ejectives and shorter for slack ejectives. The VOT's of ejective affricates in Lushootseed is longer than plain (voiceless pulmonic) affricates, which may suggest that ejective affricates in Lushootseed are stiff. However, the voice onset quality of ejective affricates has properties of slack ejectives (i.e., depressed f0, creaky voice onset, and greater intensity difference at voice onset). This mixture of stiff and slack ejectives reveals that Lushootseed ejective affricates cannot be classified exclusively as either stiff or slack.

Given the consistently falling intensity of the release frication across ejectives in the data, intensity characteristics of the affricates release frication across laryngeal types do not seem to vary along stiff vs. slack parameters. Rather, the consistency suggests physiological constraints in the glottal gestural timing of affricates when transitioning into a voiced source vs. a silent source. Ejectives involve a closed glottis during the articulatory release, which subsequently causes a delay in voicing when transitioning from the release frication to the following vowel. This leads to a period of silence following the release of ejectives. The intensity of the affricates' release frication is being pulled towards the silent period, which leads to a drop in intensity. The fact that this has also been observed in other non-Salish languages [11], [12] suggests that intensity characteristics of the affricates frication is not a typologically unique feature in Lushootseed.

4.3. Diachronic status of voiced affricates in Coast Salish
In Coast Salish, there are only three languages that have voiced affricates: Lushootseed, Twana, and Comox-Sliammon. The historical origins of voiced affricates can be inferred based on cognates found across Coast Salish languages and within Lushootseed. It is likely the case that the voiced alveolar affricate /dz/ developed from the palatal approximant /j/. For example, cognates of the Lushootseed word /dzaq’/ ‘fall’ in other Coast Salish languages include /jaq/ ‘fall’ in Squamish and /jeq’/ in Hul’q’umi’num’. This suggests that the sound change might be */j/ > /dz/. This may have been phonetically motivated by domain-initial strengthening.

Evidence of domain-initial strengthening can be observed when /dz/ occurs in word-initial position. As the current findings reveal, /dz/ is sometimes realized with a positive VOT in this position, which suggests that domain-initial strengthening might play a factor in the diachronic shift in the language. Domain-initial strengthening has also been observed in other Salish languages such as Quinalt [28] and Klallam [29]."}
